column7: 음식은 뭐 다른곳과 별반 다르지 않앗구요 물가 앞이라 물놀이는 좋앗는데 음식주문할때 인터폰하면 잘 못알아들으시기도 하고 앞치마나 그외 컵 이런거 누락 너무 많이 되구요 앞치마 받으려고 20분넘게 걸림.. 그리고 물건 갇가주시고 계산 받아가시는데.. 그분들이.. 의사소통이 서로 잘안돼어서 많이 햇갈렷어요
계곡물도 마니흐르고 시원하니 좋았어요... 한일산장 강추합니다..  음식도 깔끔하더라구요
모든시민이~자유로이 이용할수있어야하는데~계곡으로 자유롭게 들어갈수없어 불편하네요~올해같은 날씨에 쉴곳을찾아갔지만 실망했습니다,,,
대기실이 없네요.추운날 밖에서 기다리다 감기걸림

Foreigners maybe think to be just one of the squares, but it is a special place for Koreans.   First of all it is a capital city of the Republic of Korea, it means the center of the Republic of Korea.

column1: Many democratization protests have been held in the process of democratization of the Republic of Korea, and sometimes cultural festivals and concerts are held for citizens.
Since 2002 Korea World Cup, millions of citizens enjoyed the festival, cheering for soccer in the square.
In the winter season, ice rinks are built and citizens are enjoy skating.

column7: The ice skating only open for a month in every year which is winter time only. You can skate for a cheap price which is only 1,000￦ for 1 hour. It's okay even if you don't really know how to skate since most of the people that went here are the same.
it's an okay place to go but the ice rink is smaller than a hockey rink. Which I think is then a bit disappointing? Nonetheless I had a good time
Lots of fun. Need to be careful with the ice though, some rough spots
Great activity. Inexpensive and invaluable.
길이 잘 정비돼있어서 부담없이 다녀오기 좋아요.
Crazy mix of buildings and fun vibe.  Like a small scale Vegas.
Only place in USA style arround seoul. People can speek English. Some western foods can be found. Great for night life.
Fresh salmon and other seafood as side-dish.
Good to dinner with friends, nice food.
It's starting to become more westernized. Stay away if you want to experience the real Korea.
Tried night hike with a meetup group. My photos are not good as the ones taken by S company's newest model. The view from the top let you forget about the sweat you shed along the way.

This mountain close to the palaces is a great place for a pleasant and not very difficult hike. The view from the top is great. You have a panoramic view of Seoul which together with the walk along the city hall is worth the efort.

These are from the trails on the East side of the mountain.  Very easy walk up.  Blue trail is stroller friendly and Red trail gives a nice hike and views.  Both trails lead to a great observation point overlooking Seoul.
Nice spot to hike if you don’t wanna drive long.

We took Inwangsan hillside by accident, We went to see Gyeongbokgung but it was close every tuesday we look around and saw a little trail up the hill in the background didn't knew is was Inwangsan hill, decided to see if there was a trail up the hill, on our way there was lot's of café shops, restaurants and we found this small burger place just before the trail starts that made some delious brugers and fries. Found out there's three peak on Inwangsan hil, you can take all three peak's if you are in good shape we took the first peak, along the trail you can look down to some amazing view's it only gets better the higher you go, getting to the top can be a bit dangerous so always go with some friends there are medical staff going up and down the trail should you injure yourself. Pick a sunny day to go and don't forget water and snacks and enjoy the journey, highly recommeded.
Crazy mix of buildings and fun vibe.  Like a small scale Vegas.
Only place in USA style arround seoul. People can speek English. Some western foods can be found. Great for night life.
Fresh salmon and other seafood as side-dish.
Good to dinner with friends, nice food.
It's starting to become more westernized. Stay away if you want to experience the real Korea.
So much history & excellent exhibits

column1: This war museum in Seoul South Korea was such a great experience!

I went there in December 2015 on a business trip & I was amazed at how well put together the exhibits are. A few of them are audio-visual & interactive. They do a great job at educating foreigners like myself & locals alike of this trying time in South Korean history.
Definitely recommended to go there at least once

column7: A must-see if you’re in Seoul. It’s a great memorial/museum. Lots of military hardware displayed outside. It’s very cool if you’re into that sort of thing. You can pretty much sit in/on most of the military gear. Great for photos. And the museum part of it is also very cool. Lots of history and historical significance of the most recent wars that have shaped this peninsula. I think the admission is free if I remember it correctly.

This museum is free of charge and is huge as well. It also offers a good explanation on Korean history for a newcomer like me, which was nice. I wouldn't necessarily call it a "children friendly museum", but then again I don't have kids. I also assume that the target audience is adults and not children so it really doesn't matter.

column1: All in all this is a great museum for people interested in Korea. We visited this museum before we did a day trip to the DMZ. This was very helpful as we understood a lot more of the tour guides explanation.

column7: **** THE GOOD:

column1: We went during a super hot summer day, on a Monday when the museum was CLOSED for the day (every Monday, plus maybe Sunday).
We were able to walk through the outside of the large granite buildings, and also walked through the outdoor exhibit of military equipment, like tanks, artillery, jets, etc.
I can only imagine what the inside was like, but the scale of the entire museum grounds was super impressive.
I walked around the “ring of honor” style placates, commemorating the different countries that sent soldiers to Korea to fight (and die) during the “conflict”, aka “war”.

I was surprised (or not really) that France sent a pitifully small number of soldiers (like 700 soldiers) while other much smaller and less developed countries sent so many more.  Haha.  Just a joking jab again the French!

Based on the super impressive scale of the grounds, and because I’m personally interested in old-fogey things like war museums, I would definitely go back on a non-Monday and also when the weather is cooler.

column7: The War Memorial of Korea (free entry) is an important attraction dedicated to the Korean War which raged over the Korean Peninsula during the early 1950s. There are six themed halls and a large outdoor exhibition area where you can spend several hours learning about the Korean conflict. Note the museum is closed on Mondays.

column1: As you approach the War Memorial, you will see several large outdoor monuments which set the stage for a educational it not sombre experience of visiting an attraction like this. There are also numerous military vehicles, planes, vessels, equipment in the outdoor exhibition area that are worth spending time to view before or after you enter the monument to explore the halls within.

Exhibition rooms do a good job of presenting the war in a mixed variety of ways and medium; traditional text and figurative displays, cased displays, wall maps, sounds of the war and even 4D experience of MacArthur's landing at Inchon. In this manner, there is a nice effort to make the memorial as accessible as possible to a younger audience, who might not enjoy traditional war and military museums.

At the War Memorial you will find expected lockers, a cafe and gift shop at the War Memorial of Korea but no wifi, unlike the various national museums you can visit around Seoul. Photography is allowed throughout as well. You can easily spend 2-3 hours here leisurely going through the exhibition halls learning about the Korean War.

We very much appreciated our latest visit to the War Memorial of Korea. This is one of those attractions that can have a real impact on visitors, a place you want to return to during future trips to Seoul.

column7: Seoul Arts Center is a vibrant performance space. For Seoul residents, it is considered a sort of hallowed ground, which is full of various cultural performances, exhibitions and conventions. It also accommodates a number of dining facilities and coffee shops in its premises.
Its a nice place for performing arts. Haven't been to other places in Korea to compare. It feels very high classy and artistic.

column1: The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because there are better places in North America and Europe. Relative to other places in Korea, it definitely is a 5 star.

I watched the rehersal for Anna Karenina (the ballet). Hate to admit... Kinda fell asleep a couple times... Its probably because I don't have a knowledge or experience in ballet and it was just the rehersal before opening.

column7: Beautiful theater, came to see the Giacometti exhibition. Was wonderful. Check out their site they sometimes have great things on

A beautiful art center with restaurants, cafes, and shops to enjoy in between exhibits. I came here years ago for a Modigliani exhibit and was amazed by the design and organization of the center. Everyone is very welcoming here as well
Beautiful night view! The food trucks were such a rip-off but it seems no one cares. Good place for family gatherings and outings.
Central park of Seoul, destination for fitness freaks, romantists, skate boarders, picnickers and everything in between.

column1: Very well maintained roads and pleasant bicycle ride to enjoy stunning view of Seoul.

column7: Once again, like many places in Korea, its very crowded. I really enjoyed renting and riding bikes on the paved trail. You have to be cautious of the fast riders and pedestrians that J Walk and pop out in front of you. There is a water type area in the park where you can wade. The water is pretty dirty but there are tons of people that setup tents and wade and play in the water.
Awesome place to spend leisure time and hang out with family and friends. Lots of water to have fun, Street hawkers selling good food and a setup for stage performances. Loved it
Too much people at the weekend but its quite good as well. There are several food truck which you can buy all kinds of food including steak(!).
Good

Other than the Gentle Monster stores, not much to write home about unless you like to watch rich tourists or locals shop. Many overseas designer stores that are the same everywhere in the world. Did have a good time in VR Game place near by. The famous cafes were not that great as the quality of the bakery goods were average along with the coffee. Interesting architecture and decorations in these fancy cafes.
It is becoming much more commercial than it used to be. But we can find so cute cafe and restaurants. It's still crowded day and night.

Fabulous. Perfect for Street shopping. The nearest subway station is "Shinsa". It is also easy to access from Gangnam station by bus. If you want to catch the recent fashion trend in Korea, you have to come and look around. People, clothes, accessories. You will love it :)
a great place for window shopping and if you're into a good drinking scene a great place to come out and enjoy good food and good times!

Supposedly an upmarket, high-end shopping boulevard with lots of what look like gang nam gang "prancing, galloping & swaggering" in their Ferraris, Mustangs, Range Rovers and the likes. But overall it's quite a pleasant place to walk about.... certainly different from those  Myongdong crowds..
자랑스러운 우리 문화유산

column1: 태능. 조선왕조 제11대 중종의 계비 문정왕후 윤씨를 모신 능이다.

column7: 가족 소풍 짱!
5 hours climbs and down. It’s a worthy experience though the climb was tough. The view is breathtaking and it’s windy. Hikers often have snacks when taking a break up there! MUST GO
Great place for easy hiking. Multiple peaks, amazing view over Seoul. Really green nature. Doseonsa is close by.

Quite a challenging hike to reach the peak, especially for beginner. Nice view along the way and also at the peak of the mountain. Make sure you prepare water and food as likely will spent 5-6hrs at least for the whole journey to reach the peak. Also, make sure you go there earlier so that you can return to ground before the day turn dark.

We went on winter, so the landmark wasnt as good. Still, great experience. We went right to the top and went down the other side and took us around 5 hours, cause we went without the appropiate outfit.

column1: When going up was easy, but going down we needed to be a little more careful because of the snow. But they have ropes, so you can go down grabing those

column7: Amazing hike! Had a great time at the very top! Beautiful view! A must for any one in Seoul!
**** THE GOOD:

column1: This is supposed to be a traditional village in the middle of Seoul.
We went when the weather was extremely hot, and traveling with young kids.  The information center was under construction and we didn’t know where to go to appreciate this site.
We walked around aimlessly for a half hour (with whining and whimpering kids) before we gave up and walked down to the palace area.
We saw some old style homes and streets, but I’m not sure what the big deal is.  With the steep streets to traverse (with kids) it wasn’t a great experience for us.
I guess if we had found the one street where you look down through multiple old style homes / roofs, it would have been a cool photo spot.
I did find a postcard painting of that famous photo spot so at least I got that!

column7: This is the most beautiful place I've ever been. It was breath taking. People complain I see about not having it layed out for tourists - it isn't for tourists. It's a village kept original and it's beautiful with amazing views, gorgeous buildings, and the most gorgeous girls in hanbok dresses. It was like being whisked away to another world for a little while. Explore, stay quite to respect the area, and enjoy every minute of this beautiful area.
Pros:

column1: - It's a great site to take pictures in and has some craft stores along the route.
- It's a route and not a proper tourist site so we had to walk around for 20 mins trying to find some sites (1 street and many alley ways.
- It has become a residental area, it's not preserved. So the residents aren't really happy with tourist and has lots of warning signs. (Ex: GO AWAY, NOT TOURIST SITE)
Overall: If u want to take pictures here, it's a real effort to come here especially in this heatwave.

column7: The most beautiful hanok village in Seoul and, I think, in South Korea. Very nice houses and very nice view above Seoul. It's a must on your travel list, but if you go there please be quiet when you visit. People still live there and I met a lot of turists who made noise. All of the walls were full of posters "please, be quiet!" or "just visit and pass away".
Historical part of Seoul with a modern twist. Many shop's restaurants, boutique's, shop's that have some nicknack's. Bukchon Hanok Village is worth checking out.
This gentle walk along the old city wall is a must! Fantastic views of the city's past and the present in a single shot
Good for autumn walking and hiking. Lots of korean soldier here and you have to give your id before hiking
Perfect for couples and family to see Seoul.
날씨가 너무 좋아서 집에만 있기에 너무 아쉽기에

column1: 8번 마을버스 종점에서 시작해서 와룡공원을 지나 말바위안내소 에서 신분증 제시하고 방문증 발급받고 시작된 북악산 코스는
백악쉼터, 돌고래쉼터, 창의문 안내소 창의문까지 이어지는 코스인대
이 코스는 청와대 뒤쪽으로 예전에 무장공비가 넘었던 곳으로 아무때나 방문 할 수는 없으니 하절기 동절기 기간에 맞추어서 시간 확인해보시고 필히 신분증 지참하시고 방문하시기 바랍니다
날씨가 좋아서 더욱 더 경치가 좋았던 것도 있지만
경복궁 뒷쪽에서 바라보는 광화문 대로도 좋았고 남산타워와 새로 지은 잠실 롯데 타워도 한눈에 들어오고 백악마루에서 바라본 풍경은 정말 장관이였네요
보안상 사진 촬영에 제한이 있어서 다 담아내지는 못하지만 꼭 한번 방문해보시면 결코 후회하지는 않을 겁니다
아 다만 백악쉼터에서 창의문 으로 내려가시거나 올라오실때는 생각보다 경사도가 좀 있으니 조심하시기로 바라고 저는 운동화 신고 다녀왔지만 가능하시면 등산화 정도는 착용하시고 방문하시는게 좋을거 같네요

column7: 광화문 뒤편에 자리잡고 있는성곽 둘레길이 이어져 있는 북악산의 정상. 북악산보다 백악산이 옳은 이름
Nice, elegant chamber hall in which to perform and listen to music. Intimate space with audience capacity of 400. Centrally located near city hall and other tourist attractions.
Sejong Center for the Performing Arts

column1: Sejong Center for the Performing Arts is the largest arts and cultural complex in Seoul, South Korea. It has an interior area of 53,202m². It is situated in the center of the capital, on Sejongno, a main road that cuts through the capital city of the Joseon Dynasty. The center took 4 years to complete, opening in 1978. It was "built as a cultural center for Seoulites." It currently contains the biggest pipe organ in Asia.

column7: Place itself is not so special, but they have some of the best performances line ups in Korea
Awesome place! Would love to come back.

We have been here numerous times for exhibits. The content is usually not bad, but more often than not the setup, or is it called curation, is just bad. There never seems to be a theme, or any consistence with how pieces are displayed in their exhibition halls. You can look at animals not, just to suddenly have a the theme change to buildings on the same wall, for no apparent reason. The descriptions and titles of works often have wrong or confusing English and I've been told the Korean can be just as bad. We once went to an exhibit where, on one wall, withing the same apparent theme, they suddenly decided to stop using Korean on titles and switch to English, and a few pieces later, back to Korean. Definitely not high on my list of places to go regularly.

Seoul Plaza is a square shaped plaza with a an open-ground space in its centre. Situated next to City Hall in the hear of downtown Seoul, this is where free shows, concerts and other events are held throughout the year. There is even a ice-rink during winter holiday season.

column1: During our last visit (October 2017), we found Seoul Plaza ground to be in a bit poor shape. The grounds were well-trodden upon with much more dirt/mud surface than grass. It was much preferable walking on the pavement around the plaza than directly upon the centre ground space.

A stage had been setup on the pavement area next to the City Hall, where a dance performance of sorts was taking place. Plenty of seats were set up but the event seemed to have only attracted a small audience. We took watch for a few minutes before being on our way.

In the end, it really depends on what is on schedule when it comes to Seoul Plaza. Best to check the Seoul Plaza website to find out what is on during the time of your visit. Or when passing through the area, just have a quick look to see if anything interesting is taking place.

column7: Great hotel!

column1: If you want to get even better experience, invest more and get one of their sweets, because the std rooms are small and bit weired.

The location if tge hotel is great too, you can find many shopping options including very big lotte world shopping center, subway market, and their is a great shopping street nearby. I really enjoyed my stay in the plaza 2 times

column7: I went there for the Seoul drumming festival.  It's a great place to have a concert or festival.  Great access to other areas of Seoul too.

Visited the area because of the 20th anniversary of the Seoul Drum Festival. Atmosphere was great with so many seoul-lites coming down for an evening of fun. Expect the plaza to be much more quiet on your typical weekdays. Seoul metropolitan library provides a good place for a toilet if needed.

Foreigners maybe think to be just one of the squares, but it is a special place for Koreans.   First of all it is a capital city of the Republic of Korea, it means the center of the Republic of Korea.

column1: Many democratization protests have been held in the process of democratization of the Republic of Korea, and sometimes cultural festivals and concerts are held for citizens.
Since 2002 Korea World Cup, millions of citizens enjoyed the festival, cheering for soccer in the square.
In the winter season, ice rinks are built and citizens are enjoy skating.

column7: Hell parking. All of chinese merchants gathers here for duty free items
A spacious duty free shop. Good variety. Can order items here and pick them at Airport.

I am going to buy a Longchamp bag this noon in the i park duty. But, the staff told me that she could not sell the bag to me because the time I can buy the bag is over already (because my flight is tonight). The problem is that I have not seen any clear declarations of this regulation in the store or entrance. That really make me had bad impression.
Not the best DFS in seoul. But location is great.
Visit 19.9.2017: Recommend for buying korea brands especially the cosmetics. Since it has less price with no tax 3--7%.

A good exercise to trek up the hill and then be rewarded with a very nice view of Seoul from the top.  Try going up from one place and coming down from another route.  You will be pleasantly surprised by the things you see along the way.

This place is perfect for a wonderful city panorama. The path is well marked and made easier by ropes and stairs build in rock. The view from the top is amazing. You can also walk along the city wall. Enjoy finding your favourite spots: Gyeongbokgung, Namsan Tower, Blue House and many others  :-).
excellent place!!! it was my first experience about hiking, hiking is good for health, don't try if you are not physically fit for it!
A nice walk/hike along the fortress wall. Splendid views of the city too!

Here is one of the best places for light tracking in Seoul, South Korea. You can see beautiful old castles which surround city following small mountain ridge which has thick forest. In addition, you can also enjoy the panoramic view of seoul downtown on the hill.

Nice place to hang out. Visit during the evening for the scheduled rainbow waterfall show. Go with your group of friends or alone its a nice place to chill. There will music playing in the background, lots of people. You'll see youngsters with their skateboards, family having picnics, couples on their date and a lovely view of the city.

I finally was able to see the "Rainbow Bridge." It wasn't in action at the moment but to be there was good enough for me. Enjoyed meeting with a friend for the first time and visiting the CNN Cafe was great too.
A very big park along the banks of Han River. Fortunate to see the cherry blossoms here. Quite freezing sometimes.
It is the great place for taking pictures. It can make some different scenes. If you visit there 5~6 PM, you can enjoy two different pictures. :-)
A place for sightseeing. Not bad for the first time travel. You can see and experience the local culture.

This is the old Seoul Station. Now beside of this building there is a new one. And it is used as a gallery... containing the history of the station. It's quite good chance to know about it. And it's free...
Great place to visit for architecture and history.  Fabulous if you can catch an exhibit here.
a boring place to visit but nice architectures is a best place to shoot photo
Very old building
逛逛首爾新地標由MVRDV設計的天空步道"首爾路7017"，順遊免費的美術館。好羨慕首爾這麼多免費景點!

It's me again, the only Foreigner who writes decent reviews in Seoul. This is a really long river that runs through the middle of the city. They used to be a freeway. The former president of the country decided that he in a past life would take a bunch of money to pay the giant freeway through the middle of the city. He got a lot of money for it for his Construction Company. Then he became mayor of Seoul. Then he decided that he would pay another construction company gobs of money to tear the whole thing up. Now it's a beautiful River in the middle of the city that you can run next to. If you like that sort of thing. Would you should if you were in Korea. Running next to rivers is like Korea's national pastime. Isn't Korea a wonderful place? Maybe they'll give me citizenship one day.

I loved taking walks along this stream. It hides you from the crazy traffic on the surface. There are also painted graffiti on the walls which make the place look more funky. Here, people sit by the stream and dip their feet in the cool waters, even as the summer sun blazes above. It's also faster to move around here, since you can avoid pedestrian crossings.

This place in Seoul is really awesome! A green oasis in the middle of seoul city centre. It is really beautiful, I absolutely recommend to go take a walk or do some jogging there in the evening around 6 PM

This stream is honestly so peaceful and relaxing, that i would go back every time I had the opportunity to. The water is full of fishes, the side with chirping birds (and pigeons). We even saw an egret hunting for fish.
The atmosphere and the water are clean and pure, temperature near the stream is lower than the street 2-3 degrees. Fish and bird can live here, in center of a big city, it is a good environment.

column1: Carefull in a rainy day, the bank is quite slippery.

column7: Amazing palace with beautiful architecture. Entry was free with the discover Seoul Pass. We had just come from Gyeongbokgung so this place seemed smaller compared to there. The palaces looked similar on the outside but the decorations here were a bit more colourful. This place also has tours to the secret garden, the tickets are extra to the entrance ticket and located near the entrance of the garden. We had just missed the last English one for the day so decided to go to the next place instead.

Beautiful place to stroll and learn about Korean history. Guided tours of the Secret Garden are offered in English and definitely worth your time. Bonus: free admission if you are wearing traditional Korean garb! But a steal either way since admission to the general grounds and gardens won’t set you back more than $10. Final tip is to bring water since there isn’t a huge presence of concessions on the grounds.

A must see  .. beautiful place. Crowded if the tour is on a weekend but it's worth it .. you just see it once , take amazing pictures and have a nice coffee . Don't forget to got to small shop to buy a souvenir  ( we bought a magnet and some great postal cards that you don't find else where ) .... oh and an important thing ( for girls ) there are toilets hahaha.. very very clean ... ;).
Very beautiful palace. The color and architecture are so intricate. Didn't get to see the full palace as it was way too hot but will visit again.
A nice palace in Seoul. There is a bid garden in the back calls 'Secret Garden' very peaceful.

Beautiful park with the temples and the glass house. Been to the evening opening, that was a bit disappointed. There are performances, but many areas are closed and not a place for photographers hoping for a beautiful shot in the lights.

Found 1418, Historic place, National treasure, one of main 5 palaces of Josun dynasty. At day time, recommend to visit secret garden. The special night time opening is at summer times(mostly August, look it up before visiting) about a week. For locals, have to book the ticket online, but foreign visitors can buy the tickets on site. Night time visit is mostly recommended.
This palace was a zoo when I was a kid. I am sure that it's the best palace in Seoul

Hilly/slopey terrains and sceneries are awesome since the castle integrates with nature via the neighboring forest. Beautiful lake, pagoda, even a royal greenhouse, and magnificent view overlooking castle area from up above the hill. Less popular castle in Seoul, but all the more reason to like this!
It was pretty much nice journey to look around here. I visited here almost beginning of openning time and try to read some book back yard of here. Amazing moments. Oh, green house was charming also.
^^ 강남구 개포동 서초구 염곡동 내곡동 세곡동에 위치한 해발 302미터의 도심공원으로 강남구 서초구 주민의 등산 산책코스로 각광을 받는곳임. 다소 경사가 급한편이어서 쉽게 오를수 있는곳은 아님
높이  306 미터  지하철이나 버스로 접근하기 좋고 산세가  완만하여 둘레길로  적합하다  정상에서 보면 주변  조망이 아주 좋다
등산하기 좋은 곳
눈을 맞으며 핫팩 양손에 들고 갔던 기억
좋아요.

I have always wanted to try the live octopus and this place did not disappoint! There are two or more floors where vendors are selling there catches, but go to the second floor to find the octopus vendors. You can select an octopus yourself and then take it to a restaurant on the same floor and they will chop it up for you, or you can ask one of the restaurant workers to help you choose one. A small (very small, like baby) octopus is not expensive at all, and neither is taking it to a restaurant to have it prepared. They will also give you a small banchan (side dish) with your octopus.
This is a must-see place to visit if you're in Seoul. Unfortunately, I missed seeing the catches being brought in, but I hear that's really neat.

column1: They have all sorts of seafood, and the warehouse area is huge. You should definitely wander a bit amongst the stalls and see what they have to offer. (You'll also find better prices if you don't just buy from the first few stalls.) You can buy various things to cook or choose a plate that is already prepared. The vendor will guide you to a small restaurant above the warehouse, where you can cook your food/or eat it raw (if it's sashimi), and they'll supply the sides, drinks, and cooking equipment.

column7: despite the fact that there is still a divide between the older building and the new building the products there are second to none. the older building has a rustic original feel and the new building is just that, new. don't be afraid to wander around in either space as the merchants in both buildings are there to sell great seafood at a negotiable price. they speak enough English to haggle prices and each have their own selling points so shop around!

Fish market. The older section is outdoors and the newer is indoors. Lots of vendors selling mostly the same fresh seafood items. You can even have your purchased items cooked at one of many restaurants located on-site. A recommended place to visit.

We went on a Thursday evening. There wasn't much of a crowd. Throughout the market we were bugged by stall holders to buy stuff. They were mostly ladies who could speak both Korean and Chinese. Price was almost the same from stall to stall. Sanakji (small live octopus) was priced at 5K. After purchasing your live seafood proceed to level 2 of the indoor market to get your seafood prepared at the restaurants. We paid 5K per head and an additional 3K for the sashimi slicing service. The salmon belly (20K) was really good and filling.
Walruses were cute. But both were sad and depressed. Too many kids too noisy place.
Nice place for the kids. Avoid weekends.
Pretty expensive and I felt pity for animals that have pretty narrow places for surviving.
if you have kids i really recommand this place. but parking place is small. also its smaller than other aquarium i think.
Children are happy.

column1: Special place for animal contact zone at open air where you can contact with pony sheeps rabbis and others

column7: Great location in a mall. Daughter was thrilled to go. Mermaid show was nice. They did pack us in like sardines though which was uncomfortable.

Nice aquarium with a few cool fish. Very nice for families, as it is heavily aimed at kids. Get 10% off by taking a picture of the sign further in the COEX mall (or maybe steal the one I posted I suppose).
Coex shopping mall is a very nice place with a various shops and restaurants there's also a small arcade games shop. Easy to reach by Subway. Highly recommended for families.

Simply an amazing experience of underwater life. The best part was ocean kingdom. Watching some exclusive creatures in front of your eyes is mesmerizing. According to me Ticket price is bit expensive. It takes not more than 2 hours to complete the tour inside.
So beautiful and maximum kind of fishes and sea animals...  beautifully located and so calm.. also the bird sounds in the speakers keeps mind so calm...

column1: Love this place...  fit for all age groups...

column7: The buildings and scenery are very calming and serene. Walk through the park and imagine the spirits walking next to you. There's a short 13 min movie that plays on a loop in the park to educate you on the history. The cost for my wife, son and I was about $3 us. Sat and Mon you don't need a guide. All other days you do. Glad we did it.

A beautiful place to visit. There are guided tours allowed here only, which is fine because it gives a wonderful overview of the history and what each building is used for. The spirit tables are housed here and the shrine is used for ceremonial purposes. The gardens are very well kept and stunning and the building are in good repair and have been well looked after.

Visited 11th June 2018. The English tour guide was excellent in explaining the site. It was very quiet and peaceful and the size of the shrine is awe inspiring. It's well worth the price of admission.
Jongmyo Shrine is one of the UNESCO World Heritage areas in Seoul that makes for a nice place to visit if you are interested in seeing historical buildings from the Joseon Dynasty.

column1: Note: Visitation are subject to guided tours only during the week. However, you can visit independently on Saturdays.

Here you will find Confucian style shrine complexes which were used for memorial services for deceased kings and queens of the Joseon Dynasty who ruled Korean from the late 14th century until the end of the 19th century.

The Jongmyo Shrine grounds include four main clusters of buildings which you can browse around. Most are not open to view inside but you can appreciate the symmetry of their design and layout as well as the significance of their presence here.

As you walk around there are a few opportunities to glimpse into open halls, allowing you to view panelled paintings and shrine altars. Throughout, you will find signage at important walking path junctures, providing details regarding the shrine buildings in front of you.
Note: Visits during autumn means that you can see the shrine buildings during the fall foliage, providing lovely colour to time spent at Jongmyo Shrine.

column7: I enjoy the video explaining the tradition of the shrine. It would not be on the top of my list.

Nice place to get away from the city.  As of August 2018 there is a lot of construction on some of the pathways.  If you want to take a 15 minute stroll through the forest and see some interesting tombs (that have almost no explanation about them) then this is a good spot.
Very interesting place. Fascinating to follow history. Nice place even to just walk around.

There are 3 Royal Tombs preserved in this park. It is one of the most traquil and beautiful places in this hectic city. Especially, its forest is so breathtaking. In every season, you can enjoy different scenaries.

column1: Joseon dynasty's Royal Tombs are very special because these are the only Royal Tombs in that all of them are remained and preserved until now.
You can enjoy modern and ancient scenary at the same time and video that how our ancestors built these tombs. :-)

column7: Beautiful serene park. Great escape from the businesses of the city. Well worth the trip if you are looking to connect with nature.
Nice pocket forest in the middle of the city. Great for walks, reading, or learning about Korea history.
good view
Great place for sightseeing and taking a walk.
Nice  93
올림픽 공원이 낮은 언덕배기와 이와 잘 어우러진 동화같은 산책길로 연결된 아름다운

column1: 공간인데 특히 '몽촌토성' 이 있는 주변이 아름답고 매력적인 요소들이 많아 하루 나들이 장소로도 충분한 것 같습니다
서울에서 보기 드문 넓은 초원과 아름다운
그리고 이 곳에서 가장 인기있고 매력적인
그냥 보기엔 홀로이 서있는 작은 나무로
보이는데 사진만 찍으면 느낌이 전혀 달라집니다
이 곳엔 특히 젊은 친구들이 많이 오는 곳이기도 합니다
말끔한 사진얻기가 힘들어 ' 묻어 찍거나 순발력'을 요하지요.
올림픽공원의 매력중의 하나가 '사진이 잘 나오는 곳' 인데 이 곳이 특히 그런 것 같습니다
그 어디를 찍어도 예쁘고 멋있게 잘 나와서
이 곳이 넓은 초원과 지평선이 있기에
아름다운 일몰도 볼 수 있는 곳이기도
오시는 길은 지하철은 '8호선 몽촌토성역1번 출구' 입니다

column7: 처음 만들었을때부터의 시간이 많이 흘러서 지금은 대단한 토성이라고는 생각되지 않지만 현재의 기술과 비교했을때도 뒤쳐지지 않은 방법으로 쌓았다는 것을 알게되면 토성자체가 또다르게 보일 것이다.
Take a walk and enjoy the spring breezes.. I love this place
Perfect to listen to live music with friends, or hang out at night
It is the best social place for everyone.
This is a nice urban park close to the station of Hyehwa 혜화. It is a nice place for the local students and people. There are many animations.
Very nice park..
If come here on weekend there is some stall in B1 floor. It is nice design building. just enjoy it. there is many interesting place u can enjoy here. may be 1 hours enough in here
Definitely a cool looking building from the outside. The building is multi level and has a small stage (for events) on the bottom floor outside.

column1: Inside there are multiple shops and even an event floor on the bottom as well. Prices are a little higher in the stores compared to other places outside.
The area is clean with some sitting areas outside.

column7: Very nicely designed. Cool structures with futuristic features. So many instagrammable spots. The cafes are nice too. A good place to spend your time enjoying the architecture. Right outside the subway, too! Very easy to find.

You really can't hate this place. It's quiet and peaceful until the fashion show starts. A lot of trendy people come here because it's like the Mecca for hypebeasts and all that. I love it. Inside is wonderful. You really can't complain about it.

I enjoyed my visit to the Design Plaza. The shops inside sell all kinds of merchandise. The designs of the greeting cards were very beautiful. Some of the products sold had good design and were innovative. The design of the exterior in itself is pretty amazing too.

Very reasonable entrance fee. Palace is small 's ale and quite empty. Mostly in Korean. Not very interesting I'm afraid. The changing of guards at 2pm was nice. Be careful of the protests outside the main gate. Riot police too.

Interesting historical place to be visited in Seoul. Located in the heart of Seoul, you will find a little serenity in crowd. You can look back and learn from the shades of Korean past life. What makes this place unique is you can find the contrary view between Korean-style building opposite to European one.

column1: But there is no prayer room provided here. So it's less visitor friendly, especially for Muslims.

column7: This is truly a beautiful sight to see in Korea. Unlike the other famous palaces, this one is located in the heart of Seoul just down the street from city hall. From within the palace grounds you can look around and see the modern buildings of Seoul surround an ancient historical landmark. Warning a hanbok provides free entrance to the palace and touring it can feel as if you're actually a part of the Joseon Dynasty. If you're ever visiting South Korea, this is definitely a location to check out!
One of Seoul"s grand palaces. Quite interesting to observe the changing of the guards ceremony.

column1: Walked the stone-wall road  and enjoyed a very unique atmosphere

column7: If you want to visit Deoksugung or the other palace I highly recommend you to visit it with a free guide. It's a really nice experience and you learn a lot about the life of kings and queens who lived there.

column2: National Museum of Korean Contemporary History
column7: You can earn some knowledge about modern Korean hoistory. Its a free entry and well organized place. They provide a device which translates in English.

column2: National Museum of Korean Contemporary History
column7: Great overview of Korean history from mid 19th century onwards. However,  some of the displays had English translations below the Korean, while others did not, so I had to kind of guess from the context what some of the displays were talking about.

column2: National Museum of Korean Contemporary History
column7: This is one of many free entry museums in South Korea. It is very well curated and will provide someone with little or no knowledge about modern Korea with a good understanding of the country's modern origins.

column1: The displays are well described and when I first visited three years ago, it provided tablets with English commentary free of charge.
As a student of history, I look for bias in historical narratives but found little evidence of any here.

Last month, there was a special exhibition about an uprising on Jeju Island in 1948-1949. That was a bloody period on an island known for its beauty. I thought it was very well done and did some reading up on the subject when I got home.

column2: National Museum of Korean Contemporary History
column7: This very good museum in South Korea. Entery is free.You can get very knowledge from here in different languages.

column2: National Museum of Korean Contemporary History
column7: Interesting museum about the history of Korea. Entrance is free and you can read details on the exhibitions in multiple languages, from French to Spanish.

Namsan Park sits at the bottom of N Seoul Tower and offers quite a view of Seoul and its surrounding. There are several shows here during different timing of the day, where people light up the beacons on the hill to reenact a ritual from the past. Good to check the timings before you come.

column1: Aside from that nothing really special, except the place is just a park you pass by on the way to N Seoul Tower.

column7: Went to Namsan Park by bus at night. Upon reaching the top, the views of the city greeted me. A lot of people were also up here. You can go around the N Seoul Tower complex - there are restaurants and shops here. There are numerous exhibits that allow couples to declare their love for one another.
It's very wonderful place in Soul of South Korea.

column1: Everyday there is lot of people are gathering here to visit the whole city from this mountain.

column7: Varied activities to enjoy inside the park; a great way to reconnect with nature.

After a few days in Seoul we felt like some walk and this park was more or less just behind our Hotel (Pacific). A short walk brought us to the cable car station. A one-way ticket cost just 6000 won (two-way 8000). The plan was to have a stroll around on top and walk back down to the city.

column1: There was quite a line. It was always moving, but still took a bit more than an hour to get us into the actual cable car. The ride up is a matter of only a few minutes....in a very very packed cable car.
The top was a lot busier than expected. And had lots of shops and even more restaurants, really didn't see that coming.

The first thing that catches you eye surely is the Seoul Tower. But the views of the city are already quite nice from the several platforms, so we didn't go up the tower (and avoided wasting more time standing in another line).

Like I said, there are several platforms offering really nice city views. You can see quite far. Then there's the wall with the love locks. You can purchase some locks if you are interested in doing so. We didn't ... too old for this kinda thing :)

There are at least two restaurants with great city views. One is a beer / fast food place, which looked fun, but all tables were taken. The other one (indoors, but with huge windows) still had tables....but menus that cost way too much (50'000 won and up). So we just enjoyed the views without some food or drinks.
We were also lucky to catch a free show.... some warriors doing weapons-training. Quite impressive!

After an hour or so we started walking down. It's a pretty easy walk and there are several roads and trails leading back to the city. We took the one that ends around the public library at the bottom with the city walls. An very lovely walk, pretty easy with a nice little park (Baekbeom Square Park) at the end. From there it's not far to the Namdaemun Market, where we did some (more) shopping. Walk along the city wall, a nice thing to do.
All in all a good way to spend a few hours. If you have time on your hands, surely a thing that you shouldn't miss. Get some views, get some air...have a walk.

column7: The place is nice. I just didn't like the fact of having eagles in cages and chains for tourist to take pictures with. It's 2018 and we are better than that. I don't enjoy seeing animals being unhappy. The place is nice, it doesn't need the slavery of eagles.
The scenery is beautiful. My favourite part was the pond in the back with swimming fish, where i could sit down and meditate. We even saw a cat running across a bridge.

Pretty place, lots of picture opportunities.   In the summer there are also a lot of mosquitoes due to the pond.   The pond is awesome and stock with huge koi.  It's a perfect location for festivals and outdoor markets.

Free entrance. Nice place to see traditional houses. Big area. Nice area for picnic also. There are also taekwondo performance held twice a day; at 1 pm and 3 pm from Friday to Sunday. Understood that the taekwondo demonstration is only available from May to Oct.

Once you've seen one Hanok Village, you've seen them all. But, if you're going to see only one then this is definitely not a bad once to visit. There is a giant eyesore of a stage in the grounds near the entrance, but it can be forgiven when you consider the other facilities available.

column1: The buildings give a nice traditional feeling and allow for some pretty nice photos and selfies. Ditto for the garden and the large pond.
For those interested, they offer traditional wedding ceremonies from spring to autumn. Interestingly these marriages seem to mostly international marriage.

column7: I've been living in the area just for 45 days and it's crazy beautiful. Some people may find it messy and noisy but it was amazing to me as it helped me not to feel lonely in the huge Seoul. It's opened until late and from early morning you can go and find fresh fruit. The basement is full of nuts, dresses, spices and music shops, people are welcoming and easy to talk to even if you're not fluent in Korean. Plus, there is a lady selling veggies and fruit right after exit4 of the tube who has some of the best Asian Pears in town.

Definitely the place to shop and eat all the local snacks. We came early at 10 am and were able to go the shops with ease, not to mention eating. Getting a map of the place from the information booth is very important as it helps you to navigate the entire Namdaemun. The information booth is located in the middle of the Main Street. Goggle doesn’t have the names of the shop in detail.

Expect to squeeze your way through people. It is very easy to get lost here so if you are not coming alone, always know where your partner(s) is. Also, don't wander too far without knowing the place because lots of shops look similar and you will get lost. Occasionally you might find a wall with a map printed on it, but I wouldn't rely on those. Be careful. Other than too many people and getting lost, there is a lot of good street food. This can be a good place to shop because they have almost everything.

Are you hungry? There's a variety of things to eat! Do you prefer to shop? Don't worry, Namdaemun's got you covered. Do you just want to see new and exciting things? Well, what are you waiting for - go to Namdaemun! Even if you don't want to spend any money, I highly recommend still going to experience the atmosphere of a traditional market. There are people everywhere, shop owners are shouting about the items they are selling to those who might be interested, and deliverymen are swerving in and out of the crowd.
Really enjoyed the food. We first went on a Sunday late morning and there was not much open. I would recommend during the week or a Saturday.
It's a toys museum. You can cover it in half hour.

It is a great place to visit, I wished so much that kids were with me! Animation figures are just so fun. It is very easy to find, if you do Namsan cable car. Just walk 10 minutes downhill and you are there. I did not plan to visit, it was completely unexpected, but a very pleasant surprise.
생각보단 작은 규모입니다. 전시관은 초등저학년까지만 재미있습니다. 별도로 있는 애니메이션 자료관에 가면 무료로 세계 애니메이션을 dvd로 관람할 수 있습니다
오래된건물이라 더 인상적이였던.. 체험할 공간이 있어 좋았어요. 곧 새건물 지으면 또 찾아뵐께요
서울시티투어버스를 타고 남산을 가다가 내린 곳, 추억의 만화와 여러가지 애니들이 전시되어 나름 재미있었어요. 체험거리라던가 포토존 등 뭔가 아쉽기는 했지만요^^

Very interesting museum. My friends and I had a lovely time. We were given a free guided tour in English. The museum is very big so you can stay there for a long time. It is also located in a very nice place in Seoul. I would love to visit it again.

If you are a museum lover then this is a must see. It covers the whole of Korean history up to modern times and houses some master works and national treasures of this county. The building is beautiful and the layout of nothing to complain about.

column1: The museum also has two separate halls that hosts international history related exhibits. There change roughly every 3 months. I have recently seen exhibits about iron, French palaces, the Mongolians and  the ancient middle east. Some are better, some are just OK.
The gift main gift shop, near the (expensive) cafeteria has some interesting souvenirs to buy. But more importantly, it has a nice selection of books on Korea and Korean culture.

column7: Greta place to learn about Korean history, Art, Culture at one place.  If you go there by subway, we will see another awesome displays on the way this museum. You can enjoy those displays while you were on moving walk. The Museum is huge and contains lots of items telling the history of Korea. One thing to remember, in order to enter this museum, you need to go through the metal detection security gate like airports....and all your belongings must go through the x-ray machine...thus pack light!

Great exhibition for free. If you are a museum lover this is a place for you. You can skip the War Memorial near here, but this is must see. The exhibition is not biased like there, and provides decent English translations.

Great museum and very well laid out. Bottom floor focuses on history, starting with prehistory on the right side and wrapping around ending with the Japanese occupation prior to WWI. The upper floors focus on art from painting and calligraphy to pottery and sculpture. There are quite a few beautiful private collections as well. There was no Special Exhibit when I went. Attached to a Children's Museum, which is quite popular judging by the crowds, though I did not explore. 80% of exhibits included English-language translation.

Whole area is great! I went to a musical, but lots to do in the area- historical stuff, food stuff, and cultural stuff, as well as the fact that you're in modern, downtown Seoul. Parking is easy to get in but a pain getting out. Also, not cheap if you're not getting a discount from a restaurant or event. Subway stop is super convenient and feeds right into the musical hall and other nearby things to see! Oh- hotels in the area are pricey, and the restaurants too, but they are also delicious!

When you take the subway and get of at Gwanghwamun station and go to Exit 9, the view of Gwanghwamun Square will greet you with it's beautiful mountainous background. At this time (June 2018), there is also an event wherein some artist will do a calligraphy of famous quotes in Korean you can choose from their book. It will be given to you for free. It was a good starting point if you plan to go to Gyeongbukgong palace which is just few feet away.

it is an open and a very beautiful place in Korea,, the scenery was beautiful for photograph,, I dont know this place is new or old,, but somehow I can feel the ambience of Korea maybe in the 80's (maybe because the statue was an artifact? is it artifact? we dont know,,)

column1: other than that, we took some pictures here, and found a local korean man, finishing their duty in the military (i believe that it is mandatory for any men in Korea to join military for at least two years, do correct me if I'm wrong), they ask us to take their picture, which we gladly agreed to.

column7: Big square in northern part of town. Amazing views at night. Went to see a world cup match on the big screen here. The view was fantastic!
Re-enacting "City Hunter" can never go wrong. It's a nice place during sun and sub-par during rain. Was absolutely mental during South-Korea vs Germany during the group stage of 2018 World Cup.
Smaller than other major palaces in Seoul. Less crowded, too. Free entrance collects office workers nearby during lunchtime.

The palace is smaller than the others, but well preserved and quiet. The entrance is free and you can see a king's portrait and an interesting rock in the palace garden. Something different from the other palaces.
경희궁을 꼭 한 번 방문해보세요

column1: The palace in Seoul is a good place for recreation.  Seoul is often stuffy and boring, but you'll feel much better if you visit the palace. When you come to Seoul, you should visit Deoksugung Palace, GyeonghuI Palace, Gyeongbokgung Palace, and Changdeok Palace. These palaces will add something special to your memory.

column7: A nice break from the urban surroundings. A less busy palace than the other larger ones nearby.
Quiet, Nothing, Sad hisory, recommend for walking after lunch
Very descriptive, great price. Be warned it comes every 30 mins. So if you missed the bus on one of the stops thee should be another arriving
Great tours with Wi-Fi
it was so good~!! I visited Seoul last year.

column1: Within one day, I was able to see all the famous attractions.
The bus was so comfortable, clean, and the driver was so nice.
Most of all, it was really cheap!!!

column7: 필리핀에서 오신 엄마와 함께 한 서울시티투어~ 20여년만에 변한 서울을 둘러보신 엄마와의 시간 즐거웠어요^^ 좀 비싼 느낌이었던건 안 비밀~ㅋ
Soul city tour หลากหลายสถานที่ท่องเที่ยว ที่เป็นจุดสนใจในโซล ที่คุณอยากไป ภายใน 1 วัน ก็เที่ยวทั่วโซลแล้ว

column1: ค่าบริการ 10,000 won
สถานที่ท่องเที่ยว 27 จุดในseoul
ซื้อตั๋วได้ที่ gwanghwamun station exit 5

column7: This was SO FUN! We had such a blast! Every nook and cranny were filled with pictures and photo opportunities. We couldn't stop laughing and smiling. The price was great for what was available to us. I would DEFINITELY go back.
IS a trick! for your eyes! A lot of stuff to see there.. best for the families or couples. You can spend couple of hours there to have fun. VR section is for me the most recommended.

I really love spending my time here to see and capture some funny moments with the props and application that was given by the staff. The 3D effects are so cool though! Would like to visit again if I have a chance :D

I had a good time with my friend when we visited! I could finally fulfil my dream as a ballerina on stage so yeah, that’s my favourite display. The others were cool too and we had lots of fun posing at different angles.

It is a great. I was have fun with my friends.Using the apps can take the 3D video which the picture is look like alive. It was very funny to take the photo and video. There are ice museum which is very beautiful. I played on the ice slice many times. It was fast and  exciting .

Founded in 1983, Gana Art was one of the first major art galleries established in Korea. Gana have played an integral role in the rapidly growing art market in Korea for the past 30 years and Gana remain one of Korea’s most prestigious and influential art institutions today
Because it is located in several galleries, it is good for small relax.
한국을 대표하는 갤리리~♥드라마나 영화에 자주 이용되는 갤러리에용~평창동에 위치하여 주변의 조용함과 여유로움에 좋은 작품들을 구경하실 수 있어요★
장 미셸 빌모트가 한국에 건축한 대표작 중 하나. 실패확률이 적은 훌륭한 전시를 보여주는건 기본이고 공간과 지역이 주는 영감이 특히 좋다
싼곳아님.교통  왕불편
